content:
I am planning on renaming package.lean to something more generic in preparation for generalizing Lake beyond just building package targets. I also want to do this now, while Lake is in its early stages, when such a change is unlikely to cause much pain.

Currently, the two names I have in mind are the basiclakefie.lean and the more thematic, but esoteric watershed.lean. I am also considering using the later name instead for an eventual lockfile for Lake (i.e., watershed.json would instead be the JSON lockfile). I would like to know what name the Lean community would prefer. Alternatively, if anyone has another idea for a name feel free to suggest it!

I think that watershed.lean is too "clever". I would never know that it is a package configuration and would think it is a source file in the project. lakefile.lean is more likely to be connected to "makefile".
Also, is it lowercase on purpose? Most lean files have capital names, and Makefile is also traditionally capitalized
@Johan Commelin Yep, my bad. :laughing:

It should be named after what it is supposed to describe. It could use a metaphor to do so (cargo, crate, ...), but I think lake does not necessarily lend itself well to elaborate metaphors (port, harbour, marina, ...?). Something like workspace.lean would make sense if the result of invoking lake would be a working setup potentially consisting of several packages, which all are build and made available for working in VSCode. Otherwise build.lean and setup.lean would come to mind.
@Mario Carneiro, @Christian Pehle Yeah I was worried the name watershed may be a bit too "clever"
@Mario Carneiro Also, yes, the lower case is on purpose to make it clear that it is not a normal Lean module.
@Mac I don't have any immediate association of watershed related to packaging / building, the rust ecosystem is clever in that sense because they have a whole industrial metaphor going on.

@Christian Pehle really? I would never consider Rust's metaphors intuitive -- in the sense that I would naturally relate them to the relevant concepts in software packaging. They are cute/clever though. As such, I think Ruby's gem metaphors (gem, facet, etc.) -- which are not remotely connected to physical packaging -- work just as well.
Anyway, I was already leaning towards the more generic lakefile.lean and this discussion seems to be heading in that direction. Is that a fair assessment?
I did a git clone of the Lean4 source. I followed the build instructions in the Lean manual. The build stopped with errors at stage1. I have a console log. Where / How should I post it?
Don't post anything else in this thread, which is about something else. Create a new thread in the #lean4 stream with an appropriate title and ask there.
